title: Training Needs Assessment
text:
Purpose

Goal: To design an effective stock assessment training program for Somali fisheries professionals.
Objective: Identify current knowledge gaps and specific training priorities through a targeted needs assessment.
Rationale: This data-driven approach ensures the curriculum is relevant, practical, and directly addresses the needs of the participants.

title: Training Needs Assessment
text:
Our Approach

A structured questionnaire was developed to capture participant backgrounds and self-assessed skill levels.
The questionnaire was distributed for completion.
The collected data was downloaded and analyzed to identify capacity gaps and training priorities.

title: Training Needs Assessment
text: Our Approach ….

Twelve completed questionnaires.
One incomplete form and was excluded from the analysis.
The analysis is based on eleven complete responses.

Education & Expertise

Most participants hold Bachelor’s or Master’s degrees.
Primary fields of expertise are in Fisheries Biology and Marine Science.

title: Training Needs Assessment
text:
Proposed Training Module








Proposed Training Curriculum


Directly informed by the Training Needs Assessment


Module
Rationale
Key Content




Module 1: Fundamentals & Concepts
Reinforce core knowledge, as many participants rate themselves as 'Basic' or 'Moderate'.
Stock assessment principles, data types, and their application.


Module 2: Data Collection Protocols
A high-priority area. Address gaps in sampling design, quality control, and catch/effort data handling.
Practical exercises on designing sampling schemes and ensuring data quality.


Module 3: Data-Limited Methods
The most requested component and the area with the lowest self-assessed expertise (modeling).
Focus on length-based models, empirical methods, and practical application using R.

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Welcome to Module 5
Data Analysis Methods


Learning Objectives

Master descriptive statistics
Apply statistical tests appropriately
Create publication-quality visualizations
Interpret results correctly
Communicate findings effectively


Why This Matters

Transforms clean data into insights
Statistics reveal patterns & trends
Visualizations communicate clearly
Proper interpretation prevents errors
Evidence-based decisions require rigor

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
The Analysis Framework
Five-Step Process:

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Step 1: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)
Understand Your Data Structure:
# Get overview
glimpse(data)
str(data)

# Check dimensions
dim(data)

# List variables and types
names(data)
data_types <- sapply(data, class)

# Quick summary
summary(data)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
EDA: Missing Data Inspection
Visualize Missing Patterns:
library(naniar)

# Summary of missing values
data |>
  miss_var_summary() |>
  arrange(desc(pct_miss))

# Visualize missing data pattern
vis_miss(data)

# Check if missingness is random
mcar_test(data)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Step 2: Descriptive Statistics
Central Tendency:
# Mean vs Median (robust to outliers)
data |>
  group_by(fish_group) |>
  summarise(
    mean_length = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    median_length = median(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = 'drop'
  )
Dispersion:
# Spread of data
data |>
  group_by(region) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    iqr = IQR(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),  # Interquartile range
    cv = sd / mean * 100,  # Coefficient of variation
    .groups = 'drop'
  )

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Comparing Multiple Groups: ANOVA
Testing Differences Across Regions:
# Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
anova_result <- data |>
  anova_test(length_cm ~ region)

anova_result

# If significant, which groups differ?
# Post-hoc test
data |>
  tukey_hsd(length_cm ~ region)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Correlation & Relationship Testing
Length-Weight Relationship:
# Pearson correlation
data |>
  cor_test(length_cm, weight_kg)

# Linear regression
model <- lm(weight_kg ~ length_cm, data = data)
summary(model)

# Extract coefficients
coef(model)  # Intercept & slope
r_squared <- summary(model)$r.squared

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Time Series Analysis: Trend Testing
Detecting Significant Trends:
# Prepare data
trend_data <- data |>
  group_by(year) |>
  summarise(
    mean_length = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = 'drop'
  )

# Linear regression for trend
trend_model <- lm(mean_length ~ year, data = trend_data)
summary(trend_model)

# Slope interpretation:
# Positive slope = increasing over time
# Negative slope = decreasing over time
# p-value < 0.05 = statistically significant

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Effect Size Interpretation
Practical vs Statistical Significance:
# Cohen's d for effect size (two groups)
data |>
  filter(region %in% c('Berbera', 'Mogadishu')) |>
  cohens_d(length_cm ~ region)

# Effect size interpretation:
# |d| < 0.2 = negligible
# |d| 0.2-0.5 = small
# |d| 0.5-0.8 = medium
# |d| > 0.8 = large

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Step 4: Visualization Best Practices
Plot Types by Purpose:


Distribution - Histogram - Density plot - Box plot - Violin plot
Relationship - Scatter plot - Line graph - Trend line

Comparison - Bar chart - Box plot - Dot plot - Slope graph
Composition - Stacked bar - Area chart - Pie chart (avoid!)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Step 5: Interpreting Results
Key Interpretation Principles:


Start with confidence intervals, not just p-values
Effect sizes matter more than statistical significance
Consider practical significance: Is 1cm difference meaningful?
Look at data visually before trusting statistics
Account for multiple testing (adjust p-values)
State assumptions clearly about your data
Acknowledge limitations and uncertainties

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
P-Values: Common Misinterpretations
What p-value DOES mean:
p = 0.03 means:
"If the null hypothesis is true, we'd see data 
this extreme 3% of the time by chance alone"
What p-value DOES NOT mean:
✗ Probability the result is true
✗ Probability the hypothesis is true
✗ How big the effect is
✗ How important the finding is

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Confidence Intervals vs P-Values
Better Approach:
# Instead of: "p < 0.05, significant difference"
# Report: "Mean difference: 5.2 cm (95% CI: 2.1 to 8.3 cm)"

# Calculate confidence intervals
data |>
  filter(region %in% c('Berbera', 'Mogadishu')) |>
  group_by(region) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    se = sd(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE) / sqrt(n()),
    ci_lower = mean - 1.96 * se,
    ci_upper = mean + 1.96 * se,
    .groups = 'drop'
  )

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Common Analysis Pitfalls
Avoid These Mistakes:


P-hacking: Testing many hypotheses until p < 0.05
Multiple comparisons: Adjust p-values for multiple tests
Ignoring assumptions: Check normality, homogeneity of variance
Extrapolation: Don’t predict beyond data range
Correlation ≠ causation: Relationships don’t prove causality
Publication bias: Negative results are also important
False precision: Report uncertainty appropriately

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Handling Multiple Comparisons
Correction Methods:
# Bonferroni correction (conservative)
alpha_adjusted <- 0.05 / number_of_tests

# FDR (false discovery rate) correction (liberal)
p_values <- c(0.001, 0.023, 0.045, 0.089, 0.12)
p_adjust(p_values, method = 'BH')  # Benjamini-Hochberg

# Built-in: Tukey HSD for multiple comparisons
data |>
  tukey_hsd(length_cm ~ region)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Regression: Understanding Assumptions
Before Running Linear Model:
# 1. Linearity: visual inspection
plot(data$length_cm, data$weight_kg)

# 2. Normality: residuals should be normal
model <- lm(weight_kg ~ length_cm, data = data)
shapiro.test(residuals(model))

# 3. Homogeneity of variance
data |>
  levene_test(weight_kg ~ region)

# 4. Independence: no autocorrelation
car::durbinWatsonTest(model)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Reporting Statistical Results
Standard Format:






Note


Good reporting: > “Mean length differed significantly between regions (F₂,₉₈ = 4.52, p = 0.013). Berbera fish were larger (M = 35.2, SD = 5.1) than Mogadishu (M = 32.1, SD = 4.8).”
Include: - Test statistic (F, t, χ²) - Degrees of freedom - P-value - Descriptive statistics (means, SDs) - Effect size when appropriate

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Creating Analysis Reports
R Markdown Template:
# file: analysis_report.Rmd
---
title: "Stock Assessment Report 2024"
author: "Data Analyst"
date: "2025-12-12"
output: html_document
---

# Executive Summary
Key findings and recommendations

# Methods
Data sources, analytical approaches

# Results
Figures and tables with interpretation

# Discussion
What do results mean?

# Conclusion
Recommendations for management

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Automating Analysis Reports
Generate Reports Programmatically:
# file: generate_regional_reports.R
regions <- unique(data$region)

for (region in regions) {
  regional_data <- filter(data, region == !!region)
  
  rmarkdown::render(
    'templates/regional_assessment.Rmd',
    params = list(region_name = region, region_data = regional_data),
    output_file = paste0('reports/', region, '_2024.html')
  )
}

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Sensitivity Analysis
Test Robustness of Results:
# Remove potential outliers and reanalyze
data_no_outliers <- data |>
  filter(length_cm > quantile(length_cm, 0.05, na.rm = TRUE),
         length_cm < quantile(length_cm, 0.95, na.rm = TRUE))

# Compare results
comparison <- tibble(
  analysis = c('Full data', 'Without outliers'),
  mean_length = c(
    mean(data$length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean(data_no_outliers$length_cm, na.rm = TRUE)
  ),
  trend = c(
    cor(data$year, data$length_cm, use = 'complete.obs'),
    cor(data_no_outliers$year, data_no_outliers$length_cm, use = 'complete.obs')
  )
)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Bayesian Alternative: Credible Intervals
Probabilistic Framework:
library(bayesplot)
library(rstanarm)

# Bayesian regression
bayes_model <- stan_glm(
  weight_kg ~ length_cm + fish_group,
  data = data,
  prior = normal(0, 2),
  chains = 4, iter = 2000
)

# Credible intervals (more intuitive than confidence intervals)
posterior_interval(bayes_model)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Data Visualization in Reports
High-Quality Figures:
# Save publication-quality plots
ggsave(
  'figures/length_trends.png',
  plot = last_plot(),
  width = 8, height = 6,
  dpi = 300,  # High resolution
  device = 'png'
)

# Vector format for documents
ggsave(
  'figures/length_trends.pdf',
  plot = last_plot(),
  width = 8, height = 6,
  device = 'pdf'
)

title: Module 5: Data Analysis Methods
text:
Common Questions
Q: How do I handle non-normal data?
A: Use non-parametric tests (Mann-Whitney, Kruskal-Wallis) or transform data
Q: What if my sample sizes are small?
A: Use exact tests, bootstrap methods, or report uncertainty honestly
Q: Can I use multiple statistical tests?
A: Yes, but adjust p-values for multiple comparisons

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Welcome to Module 3
Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods


Learning Objectives

Apply length-based assessment models
Use empirical indicators for status
Conduct practical R-based analyses
Make evidence-based recommendations


Why This Matters

Most requested training component
Lowest expertise area identified
Directly applicable to Somali data
Actionable for decision-makers

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
What Are Data-Limited Methods?
Stock assessments when you have:


What You DON’T Have: - ✗ Age structure data - ✗ Long time series - ✗ Detailed catch history - ✗ Tagging studies - ✗ Population surveys

What You DO Have: - ✓ Length measurements - ✓ Catch data - ✓ Basic life history - ✓ Landing information - ✓ Recent time series

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Why Length-Based Methods?
Length is Easy to Measure:


Simple equipment (measuring ruler)
Minimal training required
Immediate feedback
Low cost
High consistency


Length Contains Information:
Size distributions reveal: - Population age structure - Growth rates - Fishing pressure - Recruitment patterns

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Key Concept: Growth
Von Bertalanffy Growth Model:
Fish length increases over time following a curve:
\[L_t = L_∞ (1 - e^{-K(t-t_0)})\]
Where: - L∞: Asymptotic length (max size) - K: Growth rate (how fast) - t: Age - t₀: Age at length zero

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Length-Based Methods Overview
Three Main Approaches:


1. LBB Model Length-Based Bayesian - Estimates from data - Complex but flexible - Best when trained

2. LIME Model Length-Integrated Mixed Effects - Uses length frequencies - Integrated framework - Well-developed

3. Empirical Indicators Simple heuristics - Easy to calculate - Transparent - Immediate insights

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Empirical Indicators: Length Metrics
Mean Length:
Average size of fish in catch
mean_length <- data |>
  group_by(year) |>
  summarise(mean_L = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE))
Interpretation: - Increasing trend = good (growing population) - Decreasing trend = concern (overfishing)

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Empirical Indicators: L95 & Lmax
L95 (95th Percentile):
Size at which 95% of fish are smaller


Indicates presence of large fish
Decreasing L95 = concerning pattern
Vulnerable to sampling gaps


Lmax (Maximum Observed):
Largest fish in catch

Changes with sampling intensity
Indicator of recruitment & growth
Use cautiously (influenced by luck)

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Practical Example: Somali Data Analysis
Our Dataset Recap:

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Analysis 4: Growth Estimation
Length-Weight Relationships:
# Fit allometric model: W = a * L^b
growth_model <- lw |>
  filter(!is.na(length_cm), !is.na(weight_kg)) |>
  lm(log(weight_kg) ~ log(length_cm), data = .)

# Extract parameters
a <- exp(coef(growth_model)[1])
b <- coef(growth_model)[2]

# Interpretation: b ~= 3 (isometric growth)
# b < 3 = getting thinner as grow (poor condition)
# b > 3 = getting heavier as grow (good condition)

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Interpreting Length-Based Results
What Mean Length Tells Us:


Increasing Mean Length - ✓ Stock recovering - ✓ Good recruitment - ✓ Reduced fishing - ✓ Positive trend

Decreasing Mean Length - ✗ Fishing pressure high - ✗ Recruitment issues - ✗ Population aging - ✗ Negative trend

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Reference Points Concept
Management Targets:
Define desired stock conditions:


Target reference point (TRP): What we aim for
Limit reference point (LRP): Below this = risky
Precautionary approach: Stay well above LRP


Example from Data:
# Hypothetical reference points
target_mean_length <- 35  # cm
limit_mean_length <- 25   # cm

status <- mean_length |>
  mutate(
    risk = case_when(
      mean_L > target_mean_length ~ "Low",
      mean_L > limit_mean_length ~ "Medium",
      TRUE ~ "High"
    )
  )

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Uncertainty in Assessments
Sources of Uncertainty:


Data Uncertainty - Sampling bias - Measurement error - Incomplete coverage - Missing years

Model Uncertainty - Simplifying assumptions - Parameter estimates - Biological variability - Environmental factors

Best Practice:
Always communicate uncertainty with estimates!

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Decision-Making Under Uncertainty
Precautionary Principle:
When uncertain, be conservative:
# Don't just report point estimate
result <- tibble(
  estimate = 32.5,
  lower_ci = 30.2,
  upper_ci = 34.8,
  recommendation = "Maintain current effort, monitor closely"
)

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Practical Workshop: Your Assessment
Exercise Data:
Use the Somali landing data to assess one species
Steps: 1. Filter to one fish group 2. Calculate key indicators 3. Interpret results 4. Recommend management action
Deliverable:
One-page stock assessment report

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Stock Assessment Report Template
Minimum Contents:






Note


1. Executive Summary (1 paragraph) - Stock status: Green/Yellow/Red - Key findings - Main recommendation
2. Data & Methods (brief) - Data sources - Indicators used - Time period
3. Results (with figures) - Key metrics & trends - Comparisons with history
4. Conclusions - Stock status interpretation - Uncertainties - Management recommendations
5. References - Data sources - Methods citations

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Case Study: Example Report
Berbera Tuna Stock:






Important


Status: YELLOW (Caution)
Mean length declining 2.1 cm/year (2017-2023) - 2017: 37.2 cm - 2023: 34.5 cm
Interpretation: Increasing fishing pressure or recruitment declining
Recommendation: - Monitor closely next 6 months - Reduce catch if trend continues - Increase sampling frequency

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Communicating Results to Decision-Makers
Avoid Technical Jargon:
Instead of: > “The von Bertalanffy growth model shows K=0.28, indicating asymptotic length of 55cm…”
Say: > “Fish are growing to about 55cm maximum. They reach adult size at 5-6 years old.”

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Visualizations for Policy Makers
Keep It Simple:


One main message per chart
Use traffic light colors (Red/Yellow/Green)
Show trends clearly
Label axes in plain language
Include uncertainty (error bars)
Highlight key changes

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Management Actions Based on Assessment
Green Status Actions:
✓ Maintain current fishing levels
✓ Continue regular monitoring
✓ Share success with community
✓ Document best practices

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Management Actions: Yellow Status
Caution Response:
⚠ Reduce fishing effort by 10-20%
⚠ Increase monitoring frequency
⚠ Investigate cause of decline
⚠ Consult stakeholders

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Management Actions: Red Status
Urgent Response:
✗ Implement immediate catch reductions
✗ Restrict fishing areas or seasons
✗ Emergency data collection
✗ Convene management committee

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Long-Term Monitoring Strategy
Building Your Program:
Year 1: Establish baseline - Collect data at all sites - Train staff - Test protocols
Year 2-3: Annual assessments - Compare with baseline - Detect trends - Refine methods
Year 4+: Adaptive management - Adjust regulations - Scale sampling - Expand to new areas

Data-limited methods work with what you have
Length-based indicators reveal stock status
Simple metrics often more useful than complex models
Uncertainty is inevitable—communicate it clearly
Trends matter more than absolute values
Regular monitoring enables adaptive management
Transparent methods build stakeholder confidence

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid
Don’t:


Over-interpret single year changes
Ignore measurement uncertainty
Use methods beyond your understanding
Skip quality control checks
Extrapolate beyond data range
Report false precision
Ignore biological reality

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Success Indicators
How to Know It’s Working:

✓ Decision-makers use assessments
✓ Fishers understand recommendations
✓ Data quality improving annually
✓ Stocks responding to management
✓ Stakeholders engaged
✓ Capacity growing locally
✓ Methods documented & standardized

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Troubleshooting Guide
Problem: No Obvious Trend
Cause: High variability, short time series Solution: Use longer window, increase sampling
Problem: Conflicting Indicators
Cause: Different metrics tell different stories Solution: Investigate causes, use weight of evidence
Problem: Results Don’t Match Expectations
Cause: Data issues, biological reality Solution: Quality check, consult experts, revise understanding

title: Module 3: Data-Limited Stock Assessment Methods
text:
Questions for Your Assessment
Before Making Recommendations:

What changed and why?
Is the trend significant or noise?
What’s the uncertainty?
Have I verified the data?
Do results match other evidence?
Are there alternative explanations?
What will decision-makers do with this?
How confident am I in the conclusion?

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Welcome to Module 1
Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts


Learning Objectives

Understand core stock assessment principles
Identify different data types used in assessments
Apply concepts to real Somali fisheries data
Build foundation for advanced methods


Why This Matters

Essential for evidence-based management
Reinforces foundational knowledge
Prepares for data-limited methods
Supports sustainable fisheries

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
What is Stock Assessment?
Stock assessment is the scientific process of estimating the status and productivity of fish populations to inform management decisions.
Key Components:


Population Dynamics: How fish populations change over time
Catch Data: What we remove from the stock
Biological Data: Growth, reproduction, mortality
Environmental Context: Habitat and external factors

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text: The Assessment Cycle

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
section: Types of Data in Stock Assessment
text:
Types of Data in Stock Assessment
Primary Data Categories:


Catch Data - Total landings (numbers or weight) - Species composition - Temporal patterns - Geographic distribution

Biological Data - Size distributions - Age/length structure - Growth rates - Maturity information

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Types of Data (continued)


Effort Data - Number of vessels/fishers - Fishing days - Landing site activity - Spatial distribution

Environmental Data - Oceanographic conditions - Habitat quality - Seasonal patterns - Climate factors

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Case Study: Somali Fisheries Data
What We Have in Our Dataset:


Landing records: 3,571 specimens across 6 regions
Species groups: Tuna, Mackerel, Shark, Jacks, Billfish, Rays & Skates
Time series: 2017-2023 (7 years of data)
Biological measurements: Length (cm) and Weight (kg)
Geographic coverage: Berbera, Borama, Mogadishu, Kismayo, Baidoa, Galkacyo

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Key Indicators from Our Data
CPUE (Catch Per Unit Effort)
Specimens caught per landing site per year


What it tells us: - Stock abundance trends - Fishing pressure changes - Sustainability signals

Warning signs: - ⚠️ Declining CPUE = potential overfishing - ✓ Stable CPUE = sustainable harvest

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Key Indicators: Size Structure
Average Fish Size Trends


Healthy stocks: Stable or increasing average size
Overfished stocks: Declining average size over time
Young populations: Smaller specimens dominate
Mature populations: Mix of sizes present


Why Size Matters:
Smaller fish = fewer breeding adults = recruitment problems

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Key Indicators: Species Diversity
Shannon Diversity Index
Measures ecosystem stability:


High Diversity - Many species equally represented - Ecosystem resilience - Lower collapse risk - Adaptable to changes

Low Diversity - Few dominant species - Ecosystem vulnerability - High collapse risk - Susceptible to shifts

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Key Indicators: Seasonal Patterns
Why Seasonality Matters:


Peak seasons: When stocks are most vulnerable
Off-season monitoring: Essential for baseline data
Breeding seasons: Critical conservation periods
Nomadic patterns: Species movement and migration


Somalia’s Monsoon Seasons:

NEM (Nov-May): Northeast Monsoon
SEM (Jun-Sep): Southwest Monsoon

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Stock Status Assessment Framework
Traffic Light System:


Green ✓ - CPUE stable - Size structure healthy - High diversity - Sustainable

Yellow ⚠️ - CPUE declining - Size shrinking - Diversity moderate - Caution needed

Red ✗ - CPUE low - Size very small - Low diversity - Urgent action

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Applying This to Somali Data
Our Findings Show:


Regional differences: Some areas more productive than others
Temporal trends: Changes over 2017-2023 period
Species-specific patterns: Different groups show different trends
Seasonal variability: Predictable patterns across years

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Data Quality Matters
Good Data Requires:


Collection Standards - Consistent methods - Regular sampling - Complete records - Training & protocols

Quality Control - Data verification - Error detection - Outlier assessment - Metadata documentation

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Decision-Making Framework
From Data to Decisions:

title: Module 1: Stock Assessment Fundamentals & Concepts
text:
Key Takeaways
Module 1 Summary:


Stock assessment is systematic, cyclical process
Multiple data types needed for robust conclusions
Simple indicators reveal important patterns
Somali data shows clear regional & temporal trends
Quality data essential for confident decisions
Uncertainty increases through analysis chain

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Troubleshooting Exercise

Common Field Challenges
Challenge 1: Species Identification - Solution: Use identification guide - Reference: Trained species expert - Practice: Unknown specimens brought by fishers
Challenge 2: Missing Data - Solution: Reconstruction from vessel records - Backup: Recall from fisher interviews - Documentation: Record what’s missing and why
Challenge 3: Uncooperative Vessels - Solution: Explain value of monitoring - Alternative: Sample from market - Relationships: Build trust over time
Challenge 4: Equipment Issues - Solution: Backup scales, rulers - Planning: Preventive maintenance - Contingency: Manual measurements

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text: Effective data management ensures quality, security, and accessibility of fisheries monitoring data. This module covers practical database design and data governance.

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text: Effective data management ensures quality, security, and accessibility of fisheries monitoring data. This module covers practical database design and data governance.

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this module, participants will:

Design a functional fisheries database
Implement data validation procedures
Maintain data security and backups
Create data documentation
Ensure data standardization across regions

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Data Processing Workflow
Raw Data → Validation → Cleaning → Integration → Storage
    ↓          ↓           ↓          ↓           ↓
  Forms    Range checks  Outliers  Consolidate  Archive
           Duplicates    Errors    De-conflict  Backup
           Logic         Missing   Harmonize    Access

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Data Validation

Automated Checks

Range validation (e.g., length > 0)
Type validation (numeric, text, date)
Duplicate detection
Consistency rules (e.g., length increases with age)



Manual Review

Outlier investigation
Biologically implausible values
Data entry errors
Missing values assessment

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Database Design

Relational Database Structure

Vessels table
Landings table
Species catch table
Individual fish measurements
Metadata and documentation



Key Features

Unique identifiers for all records
Referential integrity
Audit trails
User access controls

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Tools and Platforms

Options for Somali Implementation

PostgreSQL - Robust, open-source, scalable
SQLite - Lightweight, portable
Excel with validation - Simple, limited capacity
Microsoft Access - Medium complexity, Windows-based



Cloud Solutions

Secure data hosting
Centralized access
Automated backups
Remote collaboration

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Data Documentation

Essential Documentation

Data dictionary (field definitions)
Collection protocols (how data was gathered)
Quality flags (data issues noted)
Metadata (who, when, where, how)

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Data Security

Backup Strategy

Daily backups (local)
Weekly backups (external)
Monthly backups (archival)
Redundant storage



Access Control

User authentication
Role-based permissions
Audit logging
Confidentiality safeguards

text:

title: Somali Fisheries Stock Assessment Training
text:
This training program equips fisheries professionals with essential knowledge and practical skills for conducting stock assessments. Designed specifically for the Somali context, the course bridges scientific principles with real-world applications in data-limited environments.






Important



Target Audience: Fisheries scientists, managers, and policy makers seeking to improve stock assessment capacity in East African fisheries.

title: Somali Fisheries Stock Assessment Training
text:
This training program equips fisheries professionals with essential knowledge and practical skills for conducting stock assessments. Designed specifically for the Somali context, the course bridges scientific principles with real-world applications in data-limited environments.






Important



Target Audience: Fisheries scientists, managers, and policy makers seeking to improve stock assessment capacity in East African fisheries.

title: Somali Fisheries Stock Assessment Training
text:
Course Modules


Module 1: Fundamentals of Fish Stock Assessment
Core concepts in fisheries science, biological parameters, and population dynamics. Establish the scientific foundation for all assessment work.


Module 2: Fisheries Data Types
Essential data collection methods, quality assurance, and working with incomplete datasets common in the Indian Ocean.


Module 3: Length-Based Assessment Methods
Practical approaches for stocks with limited age data, using length frequency distributions and simple indicators.


Module 4: Catch-MSY and Empirical Methods
Data-limited approaches suitable for data-poor fisheries, with applications to Somali stocks.


Module 5: Integrated Stock Assessment Models
Introduction to age-structured models and integrated assessment frameworks for well-studied stocks.


Module 6: Assessment Communication & Management Strategy Evaluation
Presenting results to decision-makers and evaluating management options using assessment outputs.

title: Somali Fisheries Stock Assessment Training
text:
Learning Approach

Evidence-Based: Grounded in FAO guidelines and international best practices
Hands-On: Practical activities using R and specialist fisheries software
Context-Specific: Case studies from Indian Ocean fisheries
Flexible: Modules designed for self-paced or group learning

title: Somali Fisheries Stock Assessment Training

title: About This Training Program
text:
About TAFIRI
The Tanzania Fisheries Research Institute (TAFIRI) is the premier fisheries research institution in East Africa, established to advance scientific knowledge and provide technical guidance for sustainable fisheries development across the region.






Note



TAFIRI operates under the Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries and maintains collaborative relationships with international research institutions and regional fisheries organizations.



Why TAFIRI Leads This Training
TAFIRI’s leadership in this initiative is grounded in:







Dimension
Strength




Regional Expertise
Decades of experience conducting stock assessments in Indian Ocean fisheries


Scientific Excellence
Recognized experts in length-based methods, surplus production models, and data-limited approaches


Research Infrastructure
Modern facilities, comprehensive databases, and professional networks across East Africa


Practical Experience
Direct engagement with data-poor fisheries and context-specific assessment solutions


Capacity Development
Institutional commitment to training future fisheries scientists and managers

title: About This Training Program
text:
Course Development Philosophy
This program draws on TAFIRI’s extensive research portfolio and reflects:

Real-world relevance: Case studies from East African and Indian Ocean fisheries
Proven methods: Assessment approaches tested in similar data-limited contexts
International standards: Alignment with FAO Technical Guidelines and best practices
Regional solutions: Practical approaches to challenges specific to Somali and regional fisheries

title: About This Training Program
text:
Learning Outcomes
Upon completing this training, participants will:

✓ Conduct stock assessments using limited and available data
✓ Interpret assessment results and communicate findings to decision-makers
✓ Support evidence-based fisheries management at regional and national levels
✓ Apply international assessment standards in East African contexts

title: Module 3: Data Collection Methods

Sampling Design Principles

Key Concepts

Population: Target of inference (all landings in a region)
Sampling: Efficient way to estimate population characteristics
Stratification: Dividing population into meaningful groups
Random selection: Reducing bias in sampling



Sampling Types

Systematic sampling (every nth landing)
Stratified sampling (by vessel type, season, species)
Purposive sampling (typical vessels)
Adaptive sampling (responsive to conditions)

title: Module 3: Data Collection Methods
text:
Landing Site Monitoring

Standard Protocol

Pre-landing observation - vessel and crew info
Catch landing - species and weight recording
Length sampling - take random sample for measurement
Biological sampling - collect specimens for analysis
Data recording - digital or paper forms

Data validation rules
Supervisor verification
Regular audits

model <- lm(catch ~ year, data = data)

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Welcome to Module 2
Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design


Learning Objectives

Design effective sampling schemes
Understand quality control procedures
Master catch/effort data handling
Implement data validation protocols


Why This Matters

High-priority area from needs assessment
Addresses key implementation gaps
Directly improves data quality
Supports sustainable monitoring

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
The Data Quality Foundation
Why Data Collection Matters:


Poor data → poor decisions
Good protocols → reliable assessments
Consistent methods → comparable results
Quality control → confidence in findings


Module 2 Focus:
Practical, implementable protocols for Somali context

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Core Sampling Principles
Five Key Concepts:


1. Representativeness - Sample reflects population - Avoid biased selection - Random or stratified approach
2. Consistency - Same methods over time - Standardized procedures - Documented protocols

3. Adequacy - Sufficient sample size - Temporal coverage - Spatial distribution
4. Independence - Samples unrelated to each other - Avoid pseudo-replication - Account for dependencies

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Sampling Design Types
Stratified Sampling Strategy
Divide population into strata, sample from each:

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Sampling Approaches for Somalia
Option 1: Census Sampling
Sample every landing during monitoring period


Advantages: - ✓ No missing data - ✓ Highest precision - ✓ Detect all changes

Challenges: - ✗ High cost - ✗ Requires many staff - ✗ Logistically difficult

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Sampling Approaches (continued)
Option 2: Systematic Sampling
Sample every nth landing (e.g., every 5th fish)


Advantages: - ✓ Balanced coverage - ✓ Practical to implement - ✓ Moderate cost

Challenges: - ✗ May miss patterns - ✗ Requires discipline - ✗ Vulnerable to bias

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Sampling Approaches (continued)
Option 3: Random Sampling
Randomly select landings to measure


Advantages: - ✓ Statistically sound - ✓ Unbiased - ✓ Defensible method

Challenges: - ✗ Gaps in coverage - ✗ Lower precision - ✗ Requires planning

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Recommended Protocol for Somalia
Stratified-Systematic Approach:

Stratify by region (6 regions: Berbera, Mogadishu, etc.)
Allocate proportionally to landing volumes
Sample systematically within each region
Monthly rotations at sites to avoid bias
Document everything for quality control

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Catch Data Collection
What to Record:


Essential Variables - [ ] Date and time - [ ] Landing site/location - [ ] Vessel/fisher ID - [ ] Species/fish group - [ ] Total catch (count) - [ ] Total weight

Biological Data - [ ] Individual lengths - [ ] Individual weights - [ ] Sex (if identifiable) - [ ] Maturity stage - [ ] Condition assessment

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Effort Data Collection
What Constitutes “Effort”?


Fishing effort: Days fished, hours at sea, gear type
Landing site effort: Number of vessels arriving
Spatial effort: Geographic distribution of fishing
Temporal effort: Daily, monthly, seasonal patterns


Why Effort Matters:
To calculate CPUE, we need both catch AND effort

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Quality Control Procedures
Five-Step QC Protocol:


1. Training & Standardization - Clear protocols - Hands-on training - Refresher sessions - Competency testing
2. Real-Time Checks - Verify as collecting - Cross-checks with partners - Outlier flagging

3. Data Entry Validation - Range checks - Logical consistency - Missing value detection - Double-entry verification
4. Statistical Review - Distribution analysis - Trend assessment - Comparison with history

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Quality Control (continued)
Step 5: Documentation






Important


Every data point needs metadata: - Who collected it? - When and where? - Under what conditions? - Any uncertainties? - Contact for questions?

title: Module 2: Data Collection Protocols & Sampling Design
text:
Common Data Quality Issues

Measurement Errors - Improper length measurement - Scale calibration issues - Rounding inconsistencies - Unit confusion (cm vs mm)
Procedural Errors - Skipped fish - Incomplete recording - Wrong species ID - Timestamp mistakes

Data Entry Errors - Transcription mistakes - Transposed numbers - Missing data codes - Format inconsistencies
Sampling Bias - Selective sampling - Non-random selection - Temporal gaps - Geographic avoidance

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Stage 2: Data Import into R
Reading Common Formats:
# Excel files
library(readxl)
data_raw <- read_excel('data_shared/raw_landings.xlsx', sheet = 'Section 3')

# CSV files
data_raw <- read.csv('landing_data.csv', stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# Google Sheets
library(googlesheets4)
data_raw <- read_sheet('https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/...')

# SPSS/Stata
library(haven)
data_raw <- read_sav('data.sav')

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Stage 3: Data Cleaning
The 80/20 Rule:
80% of analysis time is spent cleaning data
Common Issues:
# Inconsistent region names
data |> distinct(region)
# Output: "Berbera", "berbera", "BERBERA", " Berbera"

# Missing values represented differently
# NA, "NA", "", "N/A", "missing", -999

# Impossible values
# Length: -5, 0, 500 cm
# Weight: -2, 0, 10000 kg

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Cleaning Step 1: Standardization
Consistent Naming Conventions:
data_clean <- data_raw |>
  # Standardize region names
  mutate(
    region = toupper(trimws(region)),
    region = recode(region,
      'BERBERA' = 'Berbera',
      'MOGADISHU' = 'Mogadishu',
      'KISMAYO' = 'Kismayo',
      'BORAMA' = 'Borama',
      'BAIDOA' = 'Baidoa',
      'GALKACYO' = 'Galkacyo'
    )
  ) |>
  # Standardize species names
  mutate(
    fish_group = tolower(trimws(fish_group)),
    fish_group = str_to_title(fish_group)
  )

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Cleaning Step 2: Date/Time Processing
Temporal Data Handling:
data_clean <- data_clean |>
  mutate(
    # Parse date field
    landing_date = as.Date(landing_date, format = '%d/%m/%Y'),
    
    # Extract temporal components
    year = year(landing_date),
    month = month(landing_date, label = TRUE),
    day_of_week = wday(landing_date, label = TRUE),
    week = week(landing_date),
    
    # Validate dates
    landing_date = if_else(
      landing_date > today() | landing_date < as.Date('2017-01-01'),
      NA_Date_,
      landing_date
    )
  )

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Cleaning Step 3: Outlier Detection
Identifying Impossible Values:
# Define biologically plausible ranges
data_clean <- data_raw |>
  mutate(
    # Flag suspicious lengths
    length_flag = case_when(
      length_cm < 5 ~ "too_small",
      length_cm > 200 ~ "too_large",
      is.na(length_cm) ~ "missing",
      TRUE ~ "valid"
    ),
    
    # Flag suspicious weights
    weight_flag = case_when(
      weight_kg < 0.1 ~ "too_light",
      weight_kg > 500 ~ "too_heavy",
      is.na(weight_kg) ~ "missing",
      TRUE ~ "valid"
    )
  )

# Review flagged records
data_clean |> filter(length_flag != "valid" | weight_flag != "valid")

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Stage 4: Data Validation
Statistical Checks:
# Distribution review
data_clean |>
  group_by(fish_group) |>
  summarise(
    n = n(),
    mean_length = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd_length = sd(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    min_length = min(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    max_length = max(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = 'drop'
  )

# Check for implausible relationships
data_clean |>
  filter(is.na(weight_kg) & !is.na(length_cm)) |>
  nrow() # How many length but no weight?

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage

text:
Data Storage Fundamentals
Storage Decision Tree:

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Option 1: CSV Files (Simple)
Advantages:


✓ Open format, no special software
✓ Version control friendly (Git)
✓ Human readable
✓ Easy to share and archive


Disadvantages:


✗ No data types enforcement
✗ Slow for large files
✗ No built-in backup
✗ Concurrent access issues


Best For:
Somali implementation with limited resources

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Option 2: SQLite Database (Local)
Advantages:


✓ Single file format
✓ Fast queries
✓ Data integrity constraints
✓ No server required


Disadvantages:


✗ Learning curve
✗ Limited concurrent users
✗ Backups manual


Setup in R:
library(RSQLite)

# Create connection
con <- dbConnect(SQLite(), 'fisheries_data.db')

# Write data
dbWriteTable(con, 'landings', data_clean, 
             overwrite = TRUE)

# Query data
data_query <- dbGetQuery(con, 
  'SELECT * FROM landings WHERE year = 2023')

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Option 3: Excel Workbooks (Moderate)
Structured Multi-Sheet Approach:
library(writexl)

# Create multi-sheet workbook
sheets <- list(
  'Raw Data' = data_raw,
  'Cleaned Data' = data_clean,
  'Daily Summary' = daily_summary,
  'Monthly Summary' = monthly_summary,
  'Data Dictionary' = data_dictionary
)

write_xlsx(sheets, 'fisheries_analysis.xlsx')
Advantages:

✓ Familiar to most users
✓ Can include metadata
✓ Easy to share

The 3-2-1 Rule:


3 Copies - Original - Local backup - Cloud backup

2 Media Types - Hard drive - Cloud storage - USB (offsite)

1 Offsite - Google Drive - OneDrive - Dropbox

title: Module 4: Data Processing and Storage
text:
Backup Implementation
Automated Backup Script:
# file: backup.R
backup_data <- function() {
  timestamp <- format(Sys.time(), '%Y%m%d_%H%M%S')
  
  # Create backup directory
  dir.create('backups', showWarnings = FALSE)
  
  # Backup raw data
  file.copy(
    'raw_data/',
    paste0('backups/raw_', timestamp, '/'),
    recursive = TRUE
  )
  
  # Backup processed data
  file.copy(
    'processed_data/',
    paste0('backups/processed_', timestamp, '/'),
    recursive = TRUE
  )
  
  message(paste("Backup completed:", timestamp))
}

# Schedule weekly execution
# Windows: Task Scheduler
# Linux/Mac: cron job

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Essential Field Equipment
Measurement & Recording:


Measurement Tools - Measuring board (marked 0-60cm) - Digital scale (0-50kg capacity) - Backup ruler (waterproof) - Calipers for precision - pH meter (for water) - Thermometer
Safety Equipment - First aid kit - Sun protection - Rubber boots - Gloves - Hand sanitizer - Insect repellent

Recording Tools - Waterproof forms (laminated) - Pencils (work when wet) - Clipboard with case - Backup paper & forms - Camera for documentation - Digital recorder
Data Management - Laptop/tablet - Mobile app (offline capable) - Backup power bank - USB drives - Data entry sheets

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Equipment Calibration
Before Every Field Day:
# Create calibration log
calibration_log <- tibble(
  date = Sys.Date(),
  equipment = c("Scale A", "Measuring Board", "Scale B"),
  last_calibrated = as.Date(c("2024-01-10", "2024-01-08", "2024-01-15")),
  status = c("PASS", "PASS", "FAIL - Recalibrate"),
  checked_by = c("Ahmed", "Ahmed", "Mohamed")
)

# Record in field book
cat(
  "EQUIPMENT CALIBRATION -", format(Sys.Date(), "%Y-%m-%d"), "\n",
  "Scale: [TEST WITH 1KG WEIGHT] - Result: ___kg\n",
  "Ruler: [MEASURE REFERENCE OBJECT] - Result: ___cm\n",
  file = "field_log.txt"
)

text:
Site Preparation
Arrival Procedures:
Checklist:






Note



Meet site manager/fisher representative
Identify landing area & vessel schedule
Set up measurement station (protected from weather)
Position scale on flat, stable surface
Organize forms and materials
Brief fishers on sampling procedure
Take site photos
Note weather conditions
Confirm contact information

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Fish Measurement Protocol
Standard Procedure:
Step 1: Species Identification
Before measuring, identify fish correctly

- Use ID guide provided
- Consult fisher if uncertain
- Record common name AND scientific name
- Note any unusual features
Step 2: Length Measurement
- Use fork length (snout to middle tail fin)
- Place fish on measuring board
- Read to nearest 0.1 cm
- Record immediately on form

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Fish Measurement (continued)
Step 3: Weight Measurement
- Use tared scale (zeroed before weighing)
- Place fish in weighing pan
- Wait for reading to stabilize
- Read to nearest 0.1 kg
- Record immediately
Step 4: Additional Data
- Sex (if identifiable): M/F/Unknown
- Maturity stage: 1-5 scale
- Condition: Normal/Injured/Diseased
- Special observations: Notes field

| Mackerel| 32.1      | 8.3       | F   | 4        | Damaged|
| ...     |           |           |     |          |       |

text:
Working with Fishing Communities
Building Trust & Partnership:

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Communication in Field
Key Phrases (Somali):
English          →  Somali
Good morning     →  Subax wanaagsan
Thank you        →  Mahadsanid
What is this fish? → Kalluun yahan waxaa?
How many vessels? → Doonni yiman?
What time landing? → Saacada yahan?
Can I measure?   →  Miyaan tiri karaa?
Always:

Speak clearly and slowly
Use hand gestures
Have local assistant help
Repeat important information

Before Leaving Site: 1. Count total records collected 2. Verify all forms complete 3. Check for missing species ID 4. Review flags & corrections 5. Take photos of forms 6. Back up data to cloud 7. Thank site staff 8. Confirm next visit date

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Evening Data Entry
Process at Accommodation:
# file: evening_data_entry.R

# Import paper form data
daily_data <- tibble(
  landing_date = Sys.Date(),
  species = c("Tuna", "Mackerel", "Shark"),
  length_cm = c(45.2, 32.1, 48.5),
  weight_kg = c(12.5, 8.3, 14.2)
)

# Run QC checks from Module 5
source('scripts/field_qc.R')
daily_data_clean <- validate_landing_data(daily_data)

# Create daily summary
summary_stats <- daily_data_clean |>
  group_by(species) |>
  summarise(
    n = n(),
    mean_L = mean(length_cm),
    mean_W = mean(weight_kg)
  )

# Save to backup location
write.csv(daily_data_clean, 
  paste0('backups/daily_', Sys.Date(), '.csv'))

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Troubleshooting Common Field Problems
Problem: Scale Not Working
Solutions: - Check batteries (carry spares) - Verify scale is on flat surface - Clean sensor with dry cloth - Use backup scale if available - Fall back to weight estimates - Recalibrate after power restored
Problem: Can’t Identify Fish
Solutions: - Ask the fisher (they’re experts!) - Take clear photo for later ID - Compare with ID guide carefully - Group as “Unknown” if unsure - Mark for follow-up verification

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Troubleshooting (continued)
Problem: Fishers Uncooperative
Solutions: - Explain benefits of monitoring - Offer monetary compensation - Involve community leaders - Choose different time of day - Work with local assistant - Emphasize sustainable fisheries
Problem: Too Many Fish to Sample
Solutions: - Sample systematically (every nth fish) - Increase team size - Sample during slower period - Pre-arrange larger monitoring team - Document sampling rate clearly - Scale up numbers using sampling fraction

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Safety in Field
Personal Safety Checklist:






Important



Let someone know where you’re going
Carry charged mobile phone
Avoid isolated areas
Wear visible/professional clothing
Work in pairs when possible
Know local emergency contacts
Respect local customs & regulations
Don’t accept rides from strangers
Keep valuables secure
Check weather before departure

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Health Precautions
Disease Prevention:


Before Field Work - Vaccinations current - Malaria medication - Travel insurance - Medical clearance
During Field Work - Wear gloves (cuts hazard) - Wash hands regularly - Use hand sanitizer - Avoid touching face

Fish Handling Safety - Watch for sharp spines - Avoid parasites - Be cautious with teeth - Don’t eat uncooked fish - Cover any cuts/wounds
Water Safety - Don’t drink untreated water - Be cautious wading - Watch for currents - Respect tidal patterns

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Site-Specific Considerations
Berbera Region:
- Large commercial port
- High landing volumes
- Mix of artisanal & semi-industrial
- Best in early morning (peak landing)
- Can get very hot
- Coordinate with port authority
Mogadishu Region:
- Variable landing patterns
- Urban setting
- Access may be restricted
- Security clearance needed
- Multiple landing sites
- Plan visits carefully

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Regional Notes (continued)
Other Regions:
Kismayo/Southern: - Remote location - Seasonal variations - Limited infrastructure - May need 2-3 day visit - Fuel availability varies
Borama/Northwest: - Semi-arid climate - Smaller landings - Community engagement essential - Water scarcity - Accommodation limited

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Three-Day Field Exercise Plan
Day 1: Orientation & Setup
Morning (2 hours): - Travel to site - Meet with site manager - Explain project - Brief on protocols
Afternoon (3 hours): - Set up measurement station - Equipment checks - Team training - Prepare forms & supplies
Evening: - Team briefing - Prepare for next day - Early rest

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Day 2: Full Data Collection
Early Morning (4 hours): - Arrive before landings - Calibrate all equipment - Greet fishers - Begin measurements
Mid-Day (2 hours): - Continue sampling - Data entry checks - Lunch & brief rest
Late Afternoon (2 hours): - Final measurements - Complete data review - Thank fishers - Pack equipment
Evening: - Data entry (all collected data) - Create daily summary - Identify problems - Plan Day 3

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Day 3: Analysis & Discussion
Morning (2 hours): - Quick field verification - Collect additional data if needed
Mid-Day (2 hours): - Data analysis - Create summary tables - Preliminary visualizations
Afternoon (2 hours): - Community presentation - Discuss findings with fishers - Gather feedback & observations - Schedule follow-up
Evening: - Final packing - Team debrief - Record lessons learned

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Data Analysis After Fieldwork
Evening Summary Analysis:
# Immediate post-collection analysis
field_summary <- daily_data |>
  summarise(
    total_records = n(),
    species_count = n_distinct(species),
    mean_length = mean(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    median_length = median(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE),
    length_range = paste0(
      min(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE), "-",
      max(length_cm, na.rm = TRUE), " cm"
    ),
    sampling_issues = sum(is.na(weight_kg))
  )

# Display to team
print(field_summary)

# Quick visualization
daily_data |>
  tidyplot(x = species, fill = species) |>
  add_bar(stat = 'count') |>
  adjust_title('Daily Catch Composition')

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Quality Assurance Program
Ongoing Verification:
# Compare measurements: Same fish, two people
comparison_data <- tibble(
  observer_1 = c(45.2, 32.1, 28.5, 41.3),
  observer_2 = c(45.1, 32.3, 28.4, 41.5),
  difference = observer_2 - observer_1,
  percent_diff = (difference / observer_1) * 100
)

# Target: <2% difference
comparison_data |>
  summarise(
    mean_diff = mean(abs(percent_diff)),
    max_diff = max(abs(percent_diff)),
    consistency = "PASS" # if mean < 2%
  )

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Unexpected Situations
How to Handle…
Dispute Over Fish: - Measure independently - Ask fisher’s opinion - Use compromise value - Document in notes
Damaged/Spoiled Fish: - Record as “degraded” - Note condition - Measure if possible - Don’t exclude from count
Fishing During Rainy Season: - Wear rain gear - Protect forms with plastic - Have umbrella for scale - Use waterproof recording
Difficult Access: - Scout location beforehand - Ask fishers for advice - Bring extra supplies - Plan longer time

title: Module 6: Practical Field Exercises at Landing Sites
text:
Communicating Results Locally
Non-Technical Presentation:


Use Simple Language: - ✓ “Fish are smaller now” - ✗ “Mean length decreased significantly”
Use Visuals: - ✓ Bar charts, photos - ✗ Complex statistics

Tell Story: - What we found - Why it matters - What to do
Ask for Input: - “Do you see this change?” - “What’s your experience?” - “How should we respond?”

title: Resource 1: Fish Stock Assessments Reports
text: This resource provides comprehensive data and methodologies for conducting tuna stock assessments in the Indian Ocean region, with a focus on Somali fisheries. It is designed to support fisheries scientists and managers in applying effective stock assessment techniques.
